c74object.name: cage.fm
c74object.description: cage.fm accepts two chords, or two rolls, or two scores, or a roll and a chord, or a score and a chord. In all but the first case, the frequency modulation is computed in time. The velocity of each modulating note is output from the third outlet during the process, and can be converted into modulation index through a lambda loop.

method.name: bang
method.description: Output the chord, roll or score obtained from the most recently received input data.

method.name: llll
method.description:
An llll in the first inlet can be a chord (expressed as an llll composed of pitch-velocity sublists), a roll or a score, and will be treated as the carrier, and will cause the result of the modulation to be output.
An llll in the second inlet can be a chord, a roll or a score, and will be treated as the modulating.

method.name: number
method.description: The velocity of each note of each modulating component is output from the second outlet, and a corresponding modulation index can be input in the third inlet through a lambda loop.

attribute.name: freqthresh
attribute.description: Sets the frequency threshold for two modulated components to be considered the same, and hence be represented as one note. This is also relevant for the calculation of the phase cancellations. The default is 10 Hz.

attribute.name: glue
attribute.description: The glue attribute, followed by two floats, sets the maximum pitch and time (in ms) separation for two consecutive modulated components to be glued together into one single note. See the gluechord message of bach.roll for more details. The default is 0 0.

attribute.name: minamp
attribute.description: Sets the amplitude of the weakest allowed component in the result of the modulation. The default is 0.001.

attribute.name: minfreq
attribute.description: Sets the frequency of the lowest allowed note in the result of the modulation. The default is 20 Hz.

attribute.name: out
attribute.description:
The out attribute is a sequence of characters identifying the outlet types (one character for each llll outlet). Characters can be one of the following:
n (default): 'native' output: faster and more precise between bach objects, but unreadable by standard Max objects (an "bach.llll" message appears instead).
t: 'text' output: slower and limited in size, but readable by standard Max objects. A plain llll in text format is a generic Max message. To keep the representation invertible (i.e., to allow a bach object receiving a text-format llll to interpret it exactly as if it was native format, except for the size limitation), some specific kinds of symbols are preceded by a backtick: namely, symbols containing parens, or containing textual representations of numbers or pitches, or beginning with a backtick, plus the symbols "null" and "nil" (distinct from the reserved words "null" and "nil" representing the empty list and the empty sublist) are preceded by a backtick. Moreover, the symbols "int", "float" or "list" are preceded by a backtick only if they are the first element of an llll, to distinguish them from the corresponding reserved messages of Max.
m: 'max' output: mostly equivalent to the "t" specifier, but no symbol is backticket except "int", "float" and "list" at the beginning of an llll. It is important to notice that, differently from text-format lllls proper, Max-format lllls might not be invertible even if they do not reach the size limit for Max message. This means that a bach object receiving a Max-format llll output from another bach object might interpret it differently from the original, or in some cases might even reject it.
x: disabled output (nothing is output)
p: 'portal' output: only used by bach.portal to intercept the @out attribute specified while creating the abstraction (see bach.portal).
The native output is recommended, unless communication with standard Max messages is needed. Disabling unused outputs can be useful if extreme optimization of the patch is needed.

c74object.discussion: Differently from other implementations of symbolic frequency modulation, cage.fm estimates the phase oppositions produced by the corresponding audio process and removes the corresponding components in the resulting chord.
